Review TiO2-based photocatalysts for CO2 reduction and solar fuel generation Tao Zhang a † Xiaochi Han a † Nhat Truong Nguyen b Lei Yang a Xuemei Zhou a * a School of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China School of Chemical Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 China School of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China b Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Gina Cody School of Engineering and Computer Science, Concordia University, Montreal, QC H3G 2W1, Canada Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering Gina Cody School of Engineering and Computer Science Concordia University Montreal QC H3G 2W1 Canada Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Gina Cody School of Engineering and Computer Science, Concordia University, Montreal, QC H3G 2W1, Canada * Corresponding author † Contributed equally to this work. Solar-driven CO2 reduction is an efficient way to convert sustainable solar energy and massive CO2 to renewable solar fuels, such as CH4, HCOOH, HCHO, and CH3OH, etc. Up to now, significant research efforts have been devoted to exploring the reaction path and developing the photocatalysts. In heterogeneous photocatalysis, among the semiconductor-based photocatalysts, titania (TiO2), as an inexpensive and practically sustainable metal oxides, remains the most extensively studied photocatalyst over the past decades. In this review, we summarize the most recent advances in the solar-driven CO2 reduction using TiO2-based photocatalysts, which include the fabrication of heterojunction, surface functional modification, band structure engineering, and morphology design, aiming to improve the CO2 conversion efficiency and selectivity to the desired product. Additionally, photoelectrochemical and photothermal approaches are introduced and the fundamental principles to activate and enhance the performance of TiO2 for the specific reaction are discussed. The exploration of the solar-driven approaches and discussion on the underlying mechanism allow the comprehensive understanding of CO2 photoreduction, that can lead to a rational design and synthesis of TiO2-based photocatalysts. Graphical abstract This review presents recent achievements in the solar-driven CO2 reduction for solar fuel generation through TiO2-based photocatalysts. The approaches, mechanisms, and strategies to improve the photocatalytic activity and selectivity of TiO2-based photocatalysts have been systematically summarized. Keywords TiO2Heterogeneous catalysis CO2 reduction Solar fuel 1 Introduction The large consumption of fossil energy leads to the increasing emission of carbon dioxide (Fig. 1 ), that creates the greenhouse effect [1]. To capture and utilize the exhausted CO2 is a multidiscipline target, that involves direct capture of CO2, adsorption or absorption of CO2 etc. [2]. One economic technique is to reduce CO2 into value added chemicals, e.g., carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), methanol (CH3OH), ethanol (C2H5OH), aldehyde [3]. However, CO2 is a very thermodynamic stable and inert compound, due to the high dissociation energy of the C=O bond (750 kJ/mol) [4–7]. It often costs high energy to reduce CO2 via a gas phase thermal treatment process, for example, a high reaction temperature (200–400 °C) or a high pressure (MPa) has to be applied to produce a desired product, making the reaction not sustainable [8–11]. To accelerate the reduction reaction, solar energy, as a sustainable energy source, can be harvested and utilized, that prevents a high demand of external energy input [13,14]. The approaches using solar energy include photosynthesis (PS) [15–18], photocatalysis (PC) [19,20], photoelectrochemical (PEC) reactions [21–26], and photovoltaics combined with electrochemistry [27]. The reduction of CO2 can be carried out in a liquid or gas-phase in the presence of a photocatalyst. In liquid phase catalytic reaction (photocatalysis and photoelectrochemical catalysis), different energy barrier, allowing reactions between protons, electrons and CO2, should be overcome according to the Latimer-Frost diagram (Fig. 2 ) [9]. Among various products, high energy density products, e.g. C2+ compounds, are preferred in the liquid electrolyte [28,29]. In a photothermal approach, the reduction reaction of CO2 takes place in the gas phase, with water vapor or hydrogen to provide protons. For industrial use, converting solar energy, hydrogen and CO2 to syngas (CO/H2 mixture) is an attracting technology [32–36] and has reached a benchmark by a Swiss research group, where CO2 is directly captured from air [37]. With water vapor, CO2 and solar energy can be sustainably converted to “synthetic” natural gas (SNG), CH4 and O2. With the assistance of solar energy, the reaction occurs at a relatively low external thermal input and at atmospheric pressure [38,39]. This approach is regarded as an artificial photosynthesis process, as the reaction demands secondary energy input (more than photoenergy), that is, the Gibbs free energy ΔG > 0 [40]. The pioneering work on the conversion of CO2 molecule to organic compounds using semiconductors by photocatalysis has been reported in 1979 by Inoue et al. [41]. Since then, various semiconductors have been developed as photocatalysts for the reduction of CO2, such as metal oxides, metal sulfides, carbonaceous semiconductors and perovskites. Among these photocatalysts, TiO2 is the most investigated, due to the relatively negative reduction potential, high physical and chemical stability, tunable band structures, environmental benign and high abundance (Fig. 3 ) [42–53]. Significant achievements on TiO2-based photocatalyst for CO2 reduction have been obtained [54–57]. Hence in this review, we focus on the investigations employing TiO2 for the reduction of CO2 assisted by solar energy. As great attentions have been directed to this field, we see the necessity and urgency to summarize the most recent published work. A comprehensive understanding on the TiO2-based photocatalysts for CO2 reduction in different configurations (photocatalysis, photoelectrochemical methods and photothermal catalysis) will be given. The methods to improve the efficiency of TiO2 and enhance the selectivity of products will also be discussed under respective configurations (Fig. 4 ). The challenges and perspectives of using TiO2 in the conversion of CO2 are proposed as well. Apparently, there are rising amount of excellent work in this field, the most recent benchmark work and pioneering work are summarized in the current review. Compared to the available reviews on CO2 photoreduction, the current review emphases on the (1) fundamental principles of using TiO2 to reduce CO2 in photocatalysis, (2) recent advances in improving the CO2 conversion efficiency of TiO2 and selectivity to desired products, (3) the fundamentals of using TiO2 in photoelectrochemical and photothermal approaches and the corresponding methods to improve the conversion efficiency. 2 Photocatalysis under open circuit potential Photocatalytic conversion of CO2, under open circuit potential (no external electric field) and in the absence of thermal energy input, has attracted wide attentions and has been perceived as a sustainable strategy to solve the greenhouse effect [58,59]. CO2 reduction reaction often couples with an appropriate oxidative half-reaction, such as H2O oxidation, or organic oxidation reaction. 2.1 Fundamentals for photocatalytic CO2 reduction A representative reaction path over a semiconducting photocatalyst includes five consecutive steps: (1) photoexcitation to generate electrons and holes, (2) efficient separation of charge carriers, (3) CO2 adsorption, (4) redox reactions on the surface and (5) desorption of products. When a photocatalyst is irradiated with light of desired wavelength (sufficient energy), electrons will be excited from valence band (VB) to conduction band (CB), leaving holes in the VB. In the third step, CO2 will be adsorbed on the surface of photocatalysts. Generally, a photocatalyst with high specific surface area provides a high density of active sites for the adsorption of CO2. In the fourth step, the electrons will be transferred to the surface of the catalysts and react with CO2 to form desired products such as CH4, HCOOH, CH3OH, etc. and water will be oxidized to O2. In the last step, the products will desorb from the photocatalyst surface [60,61]. Step 7 (Fig. 5 ) is the competing reaction for step 4, where the electrons react with protons and form H2. Step 8 is the back reaction of products with holes and form re-oxidized products. Among these steps, the charge carrier dynamics are essential to the performance of the photocatalyst and are fundamental to design the photocatalyst. The lifetime of charge carriers can be resolved using laser spectroscopic techniques, for example, transient adsorption spectroscopy, time-resolved decay of fluorescence. Fig. 6(a) shows the typical charge carrier relaxation in the photocatalyst and Fig. 6(b) gives the corresponding lifetime detected at each path in TiO2. Apparently, the lifetimes of charge carriers in TiO2 are in the time scale of microseconds or femtoseconds, indicating a slow charge transfer kinetics and a fast recombination of charge carries, that determines the reaction intrinsically. The mobility (0.1 to 1 cm2 V−1 s−1 at 300 K) [62] and diffuse length (microns for electrons and nanos for holes) [63–65] of charge carriers in TiO2 plays a key role in determining the photocatalytic reactions. When TiO2 is in contact with a secondary phase with different Fermi levels, the band bending at the interface occurs, that can further facilitate the charge transfer process (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ). The conduction type of secondary semiconductor, the doping level, the relative positions are essential as well to impact the width of band bending, W. The band bending occurs at the interface between the photocatalyst and the electrolyte, adsorbed molecules etc. In photocatalysis, the density of free charge carriers and energy levels influence the space charge regions, majority by electrons. Figs. 7(c)−(e) show the accumulation of positive charges, electrons at the surface of TiO2 and in the near surface. For example, the increase of the density of free electrons can downward bend the band. The band bending discussed here is the fundamental to the formation of junctions, for instance with metals, or with another semiconductor, that can be utilized to improve the photocatalytic performance of TiO2. 2.2 Thermodynamics and kinetics of CO2 photoreduction Thermodynamically, to convert CO2 with H2O into organic compounds is difficult without thermal input due the positive Gibbs free energy (Table 1 ). Though CO2 hydrogenation (react with H2) is favored thermodynamically, the ideal source for H2 is water, either by electrolysis, or by photocatalysis. Therefore, over the past decades, attentions have been directed to investigate the reaction between CO2 and H2O utilizing solar energy. As stated in the Introduction section, thermodynamically, energy of the electrons needs to meet certain energy barrier to react with CO2, that is, the energetic position of conduction band minimum (CBM), where electrons are produced, should be energetically favorable compared to the specific redox potential for CO2 reduction and the valence band minimum (VBM) edges should be more positive than the four-electron water oxidation potential. The standard potentials for CO2 reduction reactions are shown in Fig. 2. Semiconductors that fulfil the thermodynamic requirement on the band positions for photocatalytic CO2 reduction include metal oxide/sulfide/phosphide semiconductors [67], carbon-based semiconductors [68], metal complexes [69,70], non-metal two dimensional materials and their derivatives [20,71] e.g., TiO2 [72,73], BiOI [74], Cu2O [75], CdS [76], C3N4 [77], Bi4O5Br2 [78], ZnS [79], WO3 [80,81], and black phosphor [82]. These semiconductors with competent negative conduction band, provide sufficient driving force for electrons to reduce CO2 [83,84]. As shown in Fig. 5, eight successive steps are involved in the CO2 reduction process, including four preferred steps and four undesired processes. Except for the recombination of electron and holes in the photocatalyst (steps 3 and 6), the protons can be reduced with electrons as well (step 7), which is competing to the electron reacting with CO2. In the last step, the reduced products can be re-oxidized by holes on the water oxidation cocatalysts (step 8). Therefore, kinetically these reactions should be suppressed to enhance the activity for CO2 reduction. The selectivity of CO2 reduction can be significantly enhanced by improved kinetics in CO2 adsorption, reduction reaction and water oxidation. To reach a highly selective reduction reaction of CO2, the surface activation and reaction kinetics, the charge transfer kinetics and charge carrier dynamics should be optimized. 2.3 Approaches to improve the total efficiency (ηtotal) of TiO2 The efficiency of the total photocatalytic reaction can be determined by four components as Eq. (1): (1) ηtotal = ηabs + ηcs + ηcmt + ηredox where ηtotal is the total photoconversion efficiency, ηabs is the light adsorption efficiency, ηcs is the charge carrier separation efficiency, ηcmt is the charge migration and transport efficiency, ηredox is the redox reaction efficiency on the surface light adsorption efficiency. Therefore, to rational design a high solar-to-chemical conversion efficiency photocatalyst, four of the above-mentioned aspects need to be considered. For a certain photocatalyst, TiO2, the overall photocatalytic efficiency should be promoted by improving light adsorption ability, charge carrier utilization efficiency and efficiency in the CO2 reduction reaction. As the reactive species in photocatalysis shows no selectivity, the selectivity to a desired products in CO2 reduction can thus be controlled by the selective adsorption of CO2 by electrostatic interaction, structural confinement, or the modifications of cocatalysts. The relatively large bandgap of TiO2 (3.2 eV for anatase, 3.0 eV for rutile) and sluggish charge transfer kinetics hinder the applications of TiO2 in photocatalysis [31]. As a result, the solar light utilization efficiency and quantum efficiency are both inferior since UV range counts for only 5% of the full solar spectrum [84]. Kinetically the redox reaction occurs in a microsecond to second time scale, that indicates the lifetime of electrons should be sufficient long to participate the reaction [64,65,85,86]. However, the recombination rate of electrons and holes is in a sub-microsecond to microsecond time scale [63]. Approaches to improve the efficiency of TiO2 in CO2 reduction involve both thermodynamic and kinetic factors during the reaction, e.g., fabrication of heterojunction, surface functional modification, band structure engineering and morphological design (Fig. 8 ) will be discussed below [87,88]. These investigated methods are aiming to (1) extend the absorption range of TiO2 from UV to visible region (ηabs) [89], (2) extend the lifetime of charge carriers (ηcs and ηcmt) [90–93], (3) provide active sites to decrease the activation barrier (ΔG) [94,95], and (4) avoid by-products formation (ηredox) [19,96]. Table 2 summarizes the most recent and advanced studies on the reduction of CO2 using TiO2-based photocatalysts. Considering the reaction, two aspects will be addressed particularly, that is the conversion efficiency of CO2 and selectivity to a specific product. 2.3.1 Fabrication of a Heterojunction with TiO2 Construction of a heterojunction with TiO2 is an efficient strategy to enhance the photocatalytic activity, usually due to the enhanced light adsorption ability, the shifted band edges, the improved charge carrier transport kinetics and the possible enhanced adsorption of CO2 molecules [58,119]. In this review, five different types of heterojunctions are reported that are efficient in improving the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, including traditional Type-II heterojunction, Type-I heterojunction, p-n junction and advanced Z-scheme heterojunction, S-scheme heterojunction (Fig. 9 ). 2.3.1.1 Type-I and Type-II heterojunctions: To construct TiO2 heterojunction with a secondary semiconductor, conventional Type-I and Type-II heterojunctions are frequently investigated in previous work (Figs. 9(a) and 9(b)). However, these heterojunctions may reduce the oxidation and reduction ability of TiO2 through charge carrier transfer [120]. For example, Zhao et al. [121] construct a CeO2/TiO2 heterojunction (Type-II), where nano-layered CeO2 is immobilized on the surface of 3D ordered microporous TiO2 (Fig. 10 ). Comparing with pristine CeO2 and TiO2, the light absorption edge of the heterojunction redshifts to 500 nm from 400 nm, and the CeO2/TiO2 catalyst exhibits an enhanced production rate of CO. However, the reduction potential of CeO2/TiO2 has been reduced to –0.53 eV (Fig. 10), which applies for other TiO2-based Type-II heterojunction photocatalysts, such as, Cu2O/TiO2 [122], CdS/TiO2 [123], and TiO2/NH2-UiO-66 [124]. 2.3.1.2 p-n Heterojunction Additionally, p-n heterojunction is proposed to accelerate charge carriers separation via band engineering at the interface and the internal electric field (Fig. 9(c)) [22,125–128]. The difference in the Fermi levels allows electrons of the n-type semiconductor to transfer to the p-type semiconductor, and holes of the p-type semiconductor to transfer to the n-type semiconductor until the system reaches an equilibrium. Such electron transfer builds the internal electric field (IEF), that can drive the photogenerated electrons migrate from CB of the p-type semiconductor to CB of the n-type semiconductor, and holes migrate from VB of the n-type semiconductor to VB of the p-type semiconductor, resulting in effective separation of photogenerated charge carriers [129–131]. For instance, CoPPcs/TiO2 p-n heterojunction catalyzes CO2 reduction into CO, which exhibit a conversion rate of 4.42 mmol·g–1·h–1 and a selectivity to methane at 100% under visible light [132]. Moreover, coupling TiO2 with a secondary noble metal, the work function of which is more positive than TiO2, can form a Schottky barrier at the interface, resulting in the migration of electrons (Fig. 7) [130]. For example, the deposition of Pd on TiO2 of NiO/TiO2 heterojunction promotes the transfer of electrons from CO2 to CH4 and CO. For Pd1.0-NiO0.5/TiO2, the CH4 production rate is 49.4 µmol·h−1·g−1, however, the CH4 and CO production rate is respective 1.23 and 29.2 µmol·h−1·g−1 for NiO0.5/TiO2 [133]. Additionally the CH4 selectivity is 100% due to the Pd deposition. 2.3.1.3 Z-scheme heterojunction It is worth noting that in type I, type II and p-n heterojunction, though the charge carriers separation efficiency is improved, the trade is the reduced reduction ability of electrons and oxidation ability of holes [134,135]. Thus, Z-scheme heterojunction, imitating a natural photosynthesis process, is proposed by Tada et al. [136]. The Z-scheme junction promotes the separation of charge carriers and maintains the oxidizing or reducing ability of each photocatalyst. In an ideal Z-scheme heterojunction (Figs. 9(d) and 9(e)), two photocatalysts with staggered band structures can both be excited under illumination thus generate electron-hole pairs, respectively. The holes on the VB of semiconductor A recombine with electrons on the CB of semiconductor B, resulting in fast separation of electrons on the CB of semiconductor A and holes on the VB of semiconductor B. Such transfer of charge carriers enables the strong reduction ability of semiconductor B to reduce CO2, thus improving the photocatalytic activity of the heterojunction [137]. The Z-scheme heterojunction are divided into indirect and direct types, which depends on the existence of intermediate, for example, direct Z-scheme contains redox couple of Fe3+/Fe2+ in the solution [138,139], and indirect Z-scheme contains metals (Au, Bi, Pt) or nonmetal quantum dots (CdS, C) [76,140–142]. Sato et al. [143] have reported a Z-scheme heterojunction of p-type InP/Ru complex polymer on TiO2 as a hybrid photocatalyst, which is operated without any external bias (Fig. 11 ). The holes in TiO2 are generated under irradiation to oxidize water, thus, to provide protons to react with CO2, leading to a selectivity of HCOO– higher than 70% (Fig. 11). 2.3.1.4 S-scheme heterojunction Developed from Z-scheme heterojunction, an S-scheme heterojunction [144–146], composed of a reduction photocatalyst (RP) and an oxidation photocatalyst (OP) with different Fermi levels (Fig. 9(f)), builds an internal electric field (IEF) at the interface [147–149]. The downward bent CB of OP and upward bent VB of RP further promote the electrons on the CB of OP transport and recombine with holes on the VB of RP, leaving available electrons on the CB of RP and holes on the VB of OP. Such a fast separation of charge carriers leads to accumulated available electrons and holes, that can be utilized in the photocatalytic reaction [150]. For example, Yu's group [109] reports a core-shell photocatalyst consisting of TiO2 core and Znln2S4 shell, that catalyzes CO2 reduction into CO, CH4, and CH3OH. The Znln2S4 nanosheets are uniformly immobilized on the surface of TiO2 hollow spheres, and form intimate contact at the interface, building an internal electric field. Consequently, the total CO2 conversion rate reaches 6.65 µmol·h−1·g−1, which is 2.75 and 4.43 times higher than that of single phase TiO2 and Znln2S4, respectively. Moreover, they have developed other S-scheme heterojunctions using TiO2, such as g-C3N4/TiO2 [151], CdS/TiO2 [152] and CsPbBr3/TiO2 [113]. The g-C3N4/TiO2 photocatalyst shows a high stability during the reaction – there is no drop on the production of CO and CH4 after 4 cycles of runs [151]. However, for CdS/TiO2, prepared by hydrothermal synthesis, after 9 h reaction time, the photocatalytic activity loss for CH4 is 19% [152]. The loss of activity for metal sulfide-based photocatalyst frequently occurs, that can be ascribed to the photo corrosion of metal sulfide. To a certain extent, the formation of S-scheme heterojunction is more resistance against the corrosion compared to the single metal sulfide. The composite CsPbBr3/TiO2 shows improved photocatalytic performance in the assistance of internal electric field, that leads to transfer of electrons from CsPdBr3 to TiO2 (Fig. 12 ). As shown in XPS (Figs. 12(a)–(c)), the binding energy of Ti 2p and O 1s in TC2 have reduced 0.2 eV comparing to that of TiO2, and the binding energy of Br 3d of TC2 shifts to higher positions than that of CsPdBr3. The electron transfer is further proven by in situ XPS under UV irradiation (Figs. 12(a)–(c)). DFT calculation shows the work function of anatase TiO2 (101), rutile TiO2 (101), and CsPdBr3 (001) are respective 7.18, 7.08, and 5.79 eV (Figs. 12(d)–(f)), further indicating electrons migrate from CsPdBr3 to TiO2. The charge transfer scheme of CsPdBr3/TiO2 is shown in Fig. 12(g), which results in enhanced lifetime of photogenerated electrons (Fig. 12(h)). The surface potential at the two semiconductors of the S-scheme can be probed by Kelvin probe force microscopy [153]. Fig. 13(a) shows the microscopic images of CdS and pyrene-alttriphenylamine (PT) by Suzuki-MIyaura coupling polymerization and solvothermal synthesis with CdS. Fig. 13(b) shows the surface potential difference between point A (on PT) and point B (on CdS) is 100 mV, that reveals the formation of IEF from A to B. Under illumination, the surface potential of point A decreases due to the accepting of electrons from point B (Fig. 13(c)) [154]. Fig. 13(d) shows the decrease of potential at point A is 29 mV and the surface change at point B is 12 mV, indicating PT works at the electron donor. 2.3.2 Surface functional modification In a typical suspension system, the reaction takes place on the surface of the entire catalyst, i.e., the active centers of the catalyst [155]. Intrinsically, the surface properties of TiO2 influences the adsorption and activation of CO2, thus determining the photocatalytic activity and selectivity in CO2 photoreduction. For example, Fig. 14 shows that Ti3+ defects and oxygen vacancies (V[Os]) can be generated by reacting with photogenerated electrons and holes. Notably, these defects and vacancies (reactive sites) can bond with CO2 molecules, resulting in the activation of line CO2 molecules to the destabilized nonlinear CO2 δ•–. The reactive sites on the surface are usually thermodynamically unstable with low population and high energy, such as high-index facts, edges, steps, vacancies, etc. The reduction products from CO2 can also be tuned by the type of reactive sites. Thus, it is an effective strategy to improve the activity and tune the selectivity of CO2 photoreduction via rational modifications on the surface. In addition, the decoration of the surface with functional co-catalyst to tune the adsorption, activation, charge carrier transport kinetics etc, will be discussed [19,45,156–159]. The respective function of metal co-catalysts for CO2 reduction will be discussed in detail below. 2.3.2.1 Copper (oxides) Coppers or copper oxides are the most investigated co-catalyst for photocatalytic CO2 reduction due to the relatively negative Femi level [58,75,104,110]. As a semiconductor, the modifications of Cu2O could tune the band structure of TiO2. For example, p-n heterojunction at the interface of Cu2O/TiO2 hollow nanosphere, enhances the photocatalytic CO2 reduction rate under visible-light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm), that leading to a 1.8 folds CH4 yield (0.16 µmol·h−1·g−1), compared to that of Cu2O (0.089 µmol·h−1·g−1) [160]. Except for the conventional morphology, e.g., undefined particles of copper or copper oxides for CO2 reduction, Cu-based metal organic frameworks are applied for CO2 capture [161] and for the construction of Z-scheme heterojunction [162]. In this part, the new morphology of Cu co-catalyst, as a single atom, showing unique properties, compared to bulk co-catalyst, will be discussed. The loading of Cu1 specie can further regulate the adsorption of CO2 and activate CO2 molecules on the surface. Li et al. [163] have reported that the defective titania supported Cu1 species are active for the CO2 photoreduction to CO. The presence of surface defects (Ti3+) provides active sites for the adsorption of the oxygen atoms from CO2 molecules, and CO2 turns to be electric active species CO2 δ•– on the surface oxygen vacancy site via the interatomic interaction. Photogenerated electrons transfer from bulk TiO2 to surface Ti3+ sites and migrate to the π orbitals of adsorbed CO2. Surface Cu cations decrease the energy barrier of CO2 – adsorption and separate with CO. The surface adsorbed H2O molecule participates in the cycle as an electron donor and forms HCO3 –. 2.3.2.2 Noble metals The dominant functions of noble metals on TiO2 include the tune of light adsorption by plasmonic effect, the construction of a heterojunction junction with TiO2 to shift the band edges (discussed in Section 2.3.1), to increase the surface adsorption sites of CO2 and intermediates, and to tune the kinetics of competing reactions, thus to improve the selectivity of products. Specific noble metals, e.g. Ag or Au, within a metal size of 10 nm in diameter, often exhibit plasmonic effect that generate additional hot electrons in the photocatalytic reaction [54,164]. Comparing to Cu cocatalyst, Ag and Au remain metallic phase and effectively increase the light absorption capability via the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR). For example, Hong et al. [103] have demonstrated that by introducing plasmonic Ag to Ag@TiO2 core-shell nanoparticles (Figs. 15(a) and (b) ), the bandgap of TiO2 becomes narrower (from 3.0 to 2.8 eV) and the charge separation efficiency is improved, that results in an enhanced CO2 conversion efficiency to CH4 (Fig. 15(c)). Moreover, Pt has shown to be the most active catalyst for the CO2 reduction to CH4 among Rh, Ag, Au, Pt, and Pd on TiO2 [165]. The selectivity to CH4 is affected by the size of Pt and an appropriate loading method of Pt. To compete with H2 production from H2O, which is catalyzed by Pt, MgO is loaded on TiO2 to further enhance the formation of CH4. Wang et al. [166] have shown that the Pt nanoparticles in the size of 0.5–2.0 nm exhibit a high CO2 reduction efficiency and selectivity to CH4. 2.3.2.3 Bimetallic cocatalysts To further promote the catalytic activity of TiO2, dual cocatalysts are applied with a composite of noble metal and non-noble metal to provide sufficient adsorption and activation sites of CO2 molecules. For example, Au-Cu alloyed cocatalyst, prepared by a coprecipitation of Au and Cu precursors, has shown an improved performance for CO2 reduction reactions [92]. The photocatalyst exhibits a CO2 conversion rate of 2.2 ± 0.3 mmol·g–1·h–1 and a selectivity to methane at 97% under visible light [92]. Additionally, Au-Pd alloyed structure by photo-reduction on TiO2 [101] facet has shown to be active for the reduction of CO2 into hydrocarbons [90]. The dual sites provides abundant adsorption and activation sites for CO2. Pd atoms in the alloyed structure act as the hydrogenation centers for the reaction at an optimized ratio of Pd/Cu of 6. On the basis of [101] facet, where the photogenerated electrons accumulate, the C0–2H• radical react with H• radical and produce hydrocarbons, like CH4, C2H4 and C2H6. A high conversion of CO2 and a high selectivity of 85% from CO2 to hydrocarbons is obtained [90]. 2.3.2.4 Rare-Earth Elements (REEs) Rare earth La is suggested to be active for CO2 reduction via formation of a La–N bond structure [167]. Wang et al. [72] have found a strategy to prepare single atom Er on carbon nitride nanotubes using atom confinement and coordination. The photocatalyst shows a CH4 evolution rate of 2.5 mmol·h−1·g−1 and a CO production rate of 47.1 mmol·h−1·g−1 in a pure water reaction system (Fig. 16 ). Using DFT calculation, they have proven that on the rare-earth Er-atom catalyst, the formation of gaseous CO has a lower theoretical limiting potential than CH4 (0.3 V vs. 0.39 V), indicating a favorable production of CO rather than CH4 (Fig. 16(c)). Though CO2 reduction using REEs on TiO2 has so far not been reported, it is a promising direction to be explored. The REEs display unique electronic, optical, and magnetic properties and frequently applied in industrial manufacture. Consider the vulnerable market of REEs, rational design on the structure of the photocatalyst is required. 2.3.2.5 Carbon materials Over the past decades, carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, fullerene and g-C3N4 have attracted wide interest in photocatalysis [168–172]. First, the carbon materials show outstanding charge carriers separation ability, that can effectively improve the photocatalytic performance of TiO2. For example, dope graphene oxide (GO) on oxygen-rich TiO2 (O2-TiO2) enhances the photocatalytic performance, achieving CH4 yield of 1.718 μmol·gcat –1, that is 1.6 folds higher than that of bare O2-TiO2. The improvement is on account of the improved separation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers at the intimate interface of GO/O2-TiO2 heterojunctions [173]. Cui et al. [174] report that graphene on TiO2 suppresses the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes, leading to an increased lifetime of reactive intermediates, to hundreds of microseconds. Moreover, the presence of graphene enhances the selectivity of CH4 (12.03%) during CO2 reduction [175]. Second, the decoration of carbon materials extends the light absorption range of TiO2 to visible range. For instance, g-C3N4 coated TiO2 hollow sphere exhibits excellent activity for CO2 photoreduction under visible light, the CO2 conversion efficiency reaches 11.3 μmol·gcat –1·h–1, which is approximately 5 and 10 times higher than that of pristine g-C3N4 and TiO2, respectively [176]. 2.3.2.6 Alkaline species Previous studies have suggested that alkaline species improve the chemical adsorption of CO2, that include NaOH [177], alkaline oxide (MgO) [178], and amine functional group [179–181]. Meng et al. [177] prepare a NaOH modified TiO2 photocatalyst, with 3 wt% NaOH, the CO2 chemisorption amount reaches an optimized amount. Alternatively, modifying TiO2 with MgO, the photocatalytic CO2 reduction rate into CO improves about 4 times in the temperature range between 120 to 150 °C, and the photocatalyst shows a significant improvement in the catalytic stability [178]. Besides, amine functional groups, serve as Lewis basic sites, significantly improve the CO2 adsorption capacity [179,180]. For example, the decoration of MEA on TiO2 enhances CO2 affinity on TiO2 surfaces through chemisorption, measured by FTIR spectroscope [181]. The CH4 production rate reaches 8.61 ppm·h–1 and CO production rate is 66.75 ppm·h–1. With assistance of metal cocatalyst, the CO2 photoreduction activity can be further increased, that is ascribed to the enhanced CO2 adsorption by the localized surface charge density of metal NPs [182]. 2.3.3 Intrinsic band bap engineering As discussed above, the energetic position of CBM of TiO2 is essential in the reduction of CO2. Therefore, in this section, two different techniques are applied to engineer the band positions of TiO2, doping and defect engineering. 2.3.3.1 Dopants Unlike the particle modifications on the surface, dopants, including cations and anions, are guest atoms to the host crystal lattice and impact on the charge balance, thereby regulate the band structure of TiO2 [63,183–189]. The O 2p orbitals contribute mainly to the filled VB of TiO2, and Ti 3d, 4s, orbitals contribute mainly to the unoccupied CB [190–193]. Remarkably, the dopants bring additional electronic orbitals, or form extra chemical bonds with the host TiO2, thus significantly change the density of states. The band structure, such as the VBM, CBM, and E g therefore become regulated. Thus, dopants can extend the light absorption region of TiO2 into the visible region. In addition, the cation dopants can enhance the storage capability of photogenerated charge carriers and to create charge carrier transfer channels [189,194]. The reported dopants that are able to regulate the band structure of TiO2, include cations, e.g., Co [101], Fe [195], Cu [196], and anions, e.g., B [197], N [198,199], P [197], I [200], among others. For instance, the band structure of TiO2 can be regulated by the dose of Co [101], where Co 3d orbitals contribute to the VBM of TiO2. At an optimized molar ratio of Co/Ti at 0.025, the catalyst exhibits the highest conversion rate of CO2, giving a CH4 generation rate of 0.09 μmol·g–1·h–1 and a CO production rate of 1.94 μmol·g–1·h–1, respectively (Fig. 17 ). With an increased molar ratio of Co/Ti (0.2), the selectivity of CH4 reaches 100%, at a production rate of 0.258 μmol·g–1·h–1. Different from cations, anions usually substitute or bond with cationic Ti and form a covalent structure. For example, dope of iodine ions into TiO2 forms I–O–Ti and I–O–I bonds [200], that creates the sub band electronic states in TiO2, giving a CH4 production rate of 7.95 μmol·g–1·h–1 and CO production rate of 1.34 μmol·g–1·h–1, respectively. Surface co-doping can further tune the electronic structures and enhance the density of active sites on the surface [77,193,201]. For example, the adsorption range of TiO2 can be extended to visible light by co-doping V and W [201]. The CO and CH4 yields of V/W co-doped TiO2 catalyst is 1.91 and 0.22 μmol·g–1·h–1, respectively, which were much higher than that of single metal doped TiO2. A possible mechanism of CO photocatalytic reaction over V and W co-doped TiO2 catalyst is presented in Fig. 18 and it is suggested that the number of surface-active sites is increased by doping W and V simultaneously. The presence of W and V are in the charge states, that are possible to offer empty d orbitals for CO2 adsorption. Additionally, the co-dopants can improve the selectivity of C2+ products [202]. It is reported that Cu and Co co-doped TiO2 produce C2 products for CO2 reduction. The high selectivity towards C2+ products can be obtained by co-doping of Cu and Co, with a 0.02% Co and 1% Cu. The CO, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 yields up to 50.2, 56.6, 89.2, 3.4 μmol·h–1, respectively (Fig. 19 ). The spectroscopic technique reveals that the charge separation efficiency is improved thus leading to the enrichment of CH3• radicals on the surface of Cobalt oxide, that eventually form C2+ products. 2.3.3.2 Surface defect Defects are essential in the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 since they significantly impact on the optical, electronic, and surface properties of TiO2 [43,203–207]. The band structure, adsorption energy barrier of CO2 and electron transfer properties can be tuned by the type and concentration of defects [208,209]. The oxygen vacancy, as a point defect, can be created under relatively mild reaction condition, thus has been studied extensively. Oxygen vacancies enable improved performance of brookite in photocatalytic CO2 reduction than other polymorphs of titania [54]. Further studies suggest that CO2 reduction on a defective TiO2 surface occurs through a different path and intermediates, compared to the reaction on a pristine surface [210], that is, CO2 molecules adsorb on the defective sites and get activated [211]. Quantum mechanical modelling shows that defective TiO2 surface promotes the electron transfer from TiO2 to CO2, but the process is not energetically favorable from stoichiometric TiO2 [211]. 2.3.4 Morphology design The morphology of TiO2 affects the adsorption of CO2 and directs the electron transport path. In the past decades, increasing attentions have been directed to the modification of TiO2 scaffolds and chemical structures to improve the activity and selectivity of photocatalytic reaction, and morphology design is one of the most important modification strategies. 1D nanomaterials such as nanotubes, nanowires and nanorods can facilitate photogenerated carrier separation so as to improve the selectivity and reactivity of specific photocatalytic reactions [63]. Furthermore, due to their large specific surface area, tunable bandgap and ultrathin structure, 2D nanomaterials become valuable photocatalysts as they possess a large number of photocatalytic active sites and short carrier transport path [131]. Here we will give detailed discussion of morphology effect on the photocatalytic CO2 reduction. 2.3.4.1 Facet Crystal facets of TiO2 crystalline have different physico-chemical properties and surface energy based on specific electron configuration and surface atomic structure, that lead to shape-dependent photocatalytic properties [212–216]. For instance, Indrakanti et al. [217] calculate the adsorption behavior of CO2 on the respective TiO2 (010), (001), and (101) facet using density functional theory and find that the bridged Ti–O bond in (001) facet is weaker than that on (010) and (101), resulting in the formation of carbonate species on (001) facet. Experimentally, Yu et al. [215] have synthesized anatase TiO2 with different exposed ratio of (001) and (101) facets via controlled dosage of HF and investigated the photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction. The results show that the (001) facet of anatase TiO2 is beneficial for the transport of charge carriers, thus enhance the photocatalytic activity. The CH4 production rate is 1.35 μmol·g–1·h–1 at 55% of (001) facet in the TiO2 [215]. 2.3.4.2 Surface area Surface area affects the photocatalytic efficiency on the bases of density of active sites on the surface, that is, the catalytic activity of photocatalyst may be significantly improved at nanoscale size or in a porous structure [218,219]. For example, two-dimensional structure shows a high specific surface area and abundant active sites on TiO2. Tu et al. [220] employ a layer-by-layer assembly technique to design and synthesize a robust hollow sphere, that consists of Ti0.91O2 nanosheets and graphene nanosheets. Comparing to a commercial P25 photocatalyst, the graphene/Ti0.91O2 possesses larger specific surface area and higher density of active sites to adsorb and activate CO2 molecules. CO and CH4 formation rate are respective 8.91 and 1.14 μmol·g−1·h−1, where the total CO2 conversion rate (to CO and CH4) is 9 times higher than that of commercial P25. 2.3.4.3 Electron transport directions One-dimensional structured photocatalysts like nanotube, nanorod, nanowires, and nanobelts, have been investigated to provide a charge transfer direction, thereby improve the catalytic performance [141,221]. In addition, recent studies show that two-dimensional structures, except for the high specific surface area, also provide short charge carrier transport path [20]. For example, Tu et al. [220] show that sheeted Ti0.91O2 and graphene allow the rapid migration of photo-generated electrons, thus markedly enhance the lifetime of charge carriers. Raziq et al. [222] demonstrate that Au/TiO2 coupled with porous g-C3N4 shows a large surface area (85.5 m2·g−1), that greatly improves the separation of charge carriers. The structure is beneficial for the generation of catalytically functioned •CO2 and •H species in the redox reaction. Furthermore, the yolk@shell hollow sphere significantly improves the multi scattering of the incident light and benefit the light adsorption [91,223,224]. 2.4 DFT calculations As seen from above, the thermotical calculations are of key role to under the mechanism of the reactions [225]. Up to now, Density functional theory (DFT) has been widely used to investigate the characteristics of the catalyst, including structure, elastic constants, the band structure, density of states, thermodynamic phenomena, and the reaction path etc., which significantly promotes the analysis of the reactions. DFT is usually performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional is applied with the projector augment wave (PAW) method to optimize the lattice parameters and relax the structures of TiO2 and to describe interactions between ion cores and valence electrons. For TiO2, as a nonmagnetic material, spin-polarized calculations can be carried out [226,227]. DFT + U method should be considered in the calculation for TiO2, but the U values may have influence with the energy and magnetism (U = 3, 4, 5 and 6 eV). When the reaction path is calculated, the van der Waals (vdW) interactions between the reactants/intermediates and TiO2 can be considered using the DFT-D2 method. In photoreduction CO2, to understand the function of oxide, Kwon et al. [228] have use DFT to simulate the CO2 behavior on TiO2 that is covered with a thin basic oxide layer. They find that CO2 accept electrons and adsorb on the surface of basic oxide to form a stable state, the energy barrier on different oxide layer is in order: MgO < CaO < SrO < BaO (Figs. 20(a)–(c) ), which could be ascribed to charge difference on the surface. The different lattice constant influences the charge distribution of CO2 molecule on the surface, indicating that basic oxide is beneficial for CO2 adsorption thus for photoreduction. They further prove that the dosage of SrO on TiO2 affects the activation of CO2 and desorption of CO, with an optimized dosage of 1 monolayer of SrO on TiO2 showing the optimized photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction (Fig. 20(d)). 2.5 Further considerations As mentioned above, the methods to improve the conversion efficiency of TiO2 include the improvement on the adsorption efficiency, the kinetics of the charge carrier transfer and migration, and the surface redox kinetics. In addition, kinetically it is essential to suppress the recombination efficiency and the reverse reactions of the products. Considering the selectivity of the products, two aspects can be considered: the majority investigation is to create active sites on the surface that mediate the reaction or stabilize the intermediates to the desired products, for example CH4; the tune on the energetic positions of CBM and VBM changes the redox potentials of charge carrier that eventually impact, to a certain extent, on the selectivity as well. As a result, the modification approaches are frequently combined to reach the highest CO2 conversion efficiency and a high selectivity. For example, the improved photocatalytic activity of TiO2/CuInS2 is attributed to the Z-scheme heterojunction that facilitates the charge carrier separation and core-shell structure that provide high density of active sites. Additionally, the development of artificial intelligent for science shines a light on the design of photocatalyst. The information up to now on the CO2 conversion can be summarized and analyzed deeply and the further investigations can be guided on the information from an artificial machine. Nevertheless, though photocatalysis has huge benefits to convert CO2 into value added chemicals, the production rate and selectivity of C2+ molecules are not high. Few report shows CO2 is reduced to CH3OOCH in the presence of CH3OH using a CuO/TiO2 photocatalyst (Table 2) [106]. The production of C2+ molecules takes more steps and energy input in comparison to C1 molecules. Hence, in the next sections we introduce the photoelectrochemical method. 3 Photoelectrochemical approach 3.1 Fundamentals for photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction In the photocatalytic system, anode and cathode of the photocatalyst are integrated on one entity [229]. However, in a photoelectrochemical (PEC) setup, photoanode and photocathode are designed separately, to accelerate the conversion of CO2 and improve the selectivity of products [230,231]. The PEC system consists of three component electrodes: working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode (Fig. 21 ). Commonly, the counter electrode and reference electrode will be platinum sheet and a saturated Ag/AgCl, respectively. Briefly, the cathode and anode electrodes are connected in an external electric circuit. The working electrode will be excited under illumination and generate electrons that are transferred via external circuit. The holes on the photoanode will oxidize the reactants in the electrolyte, whereas the electrons on the cathode will reduce the species in the electrolyte. Both reactions occur at the interface between the electrodes and in the electrolyte, and the products can be regulated, e.g., formate, formaldehyde, formic acid, methane, methanol, and ethanol. The migration of electrons and protons can be driven by the applied electric field, also the redox potential between the two electrodes [232,233]. Based on the functions of a semiconductor PEC reaction cell, the PEC CO2 reduction system can be divided into three categories: a photocathode-driven, photoanode-driven and Photoanode-Photocathode (p-n junction)-driven (Fig. 22 ) [232,234,235]. In Fig. 22(a), a metal electrode works as the anode and a p-type semiconductor works as the photocathode. In the anodic cell, the water will be oxidized to O2 and H+. On the cathodic cell, CO2 molecules are reduced by the photo-excited electrons with the aid of diffused proton H+ ions [236,237]. Such configuration has been extensively studied since late 1970 when Halmann reported the conversion of CO2 for the first time. In this PEC cell the CO2 was converted into fuels directly on a photocathode [238]. An n-type semiconductor, for example, TiO2, ZnO, BiVO4, or WO3, is usually working as the photoanode (Fig. 22(b)), with a metal electrode as the cathode. When light with energy of photons equal to or higher than the band gap energy of the anode, irradiates the anode, charge carriers are generated, and water oxidation reaction occurs on the surface of the anode with the generated holes [239]. The generated electrons are transferred to the cathode for CO2 reduction reaction in external electric circuit by the applied bias between anode and saturated Ag/AgCl electrode [240]. The holes migrate to the cathode through the proton membrane and participate the CO2 reduction reaction. Ogura et al. [241] first utilized an n-type semiconductor as a photoanode for PEC CO2 reduction reaction in 1986. In addition, the combination of semiconducting photoanode and photocathode in a single system has opened as new view in photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction systems (Fig. 22(c)) [235]. The PEC cell consists of an n-type semiconductor as the photoanode and a p-type semiconductor as the photocathode, regarded as a p-n junction. Both electrodes are excited to generate electrons and holes simultaneously and the difference on the Femi levels drives the flow of electrons, thus CO2 reduction reaction on the photocathode and water oxidation reaction on the photoanode occur respectively [235]. Such configuration can be scaled up due to the absence of external bias [234,242]. In the Section 2, it has been discussed that various products can be produced due to the multiple electron transfer process in the CO2 reduction. In the PEC cell, the applied voltage in the setups in Figs. 22(a) and 22(b) is essential to determine the products. The driving force between the two electrodes in Fig. 22(c) determines the possible products thermodynamically. However, the selectivity to the target product is not high due to the similar potentials to the C1 products. Possible CO2 reduction reactions and potentials are presented in Table 3 . It is suggested that the formation of CO2 •− is unfavorable due to the large voltage to overcome and the stable linear geometry of CO2 molecules. After the addition of first electron, the consecutive multielectron reduction reactions are less challenging. Similarly, in the photocatalytic reaction, the reduction of protons H+ is competing to the reduction of CO2, thus it is important to suppress the kinetics for proton reduction by surface coating or co-catalyst loading. In addition, pH in the electrolyte influences the reduction potential of the product as well. Fig. 23 shows the reduction potential of formic acid under different pH based on the Pourbaix diagram by Hori [243]. In acidic electrolyte, the reduction potential is lower than that in the basic electrolyte. 3.2 Function of TiO2 in PEC reactions The PEC electrodes are expected to be stable in aqueous electrolyte, showing a suitable bandgap, high conductivity and appropriate adsorption of CO2 [240,253]. During PEC reaction, it is challenging to maintain a long-term stability of the electrode due to decay of the electrode by photo-corrosion, electro-corrosion, and degradation of electrolyte. In this regard, titania, as a photo- and chemical corrosion-resistant metal oxide, is an ideal scaffold for electrode and has been widely investigated for PEC CO2 reduction [31,56,113,261–263]. The n-type semiconducting TiO2 is also favorable in PEC because it produces large amounts of protons to active CO2 and reduce it into liquid fuel products [264]. Depending on the composition of counter electrode, TiO2-based electrode serves as a photocathode or a photoanode. 3.3 Approaches to improve the efficiency of TiO2 in CO2 conversion There are three types of employments of TiO2 in a photoelectrochemical setup: nanotube arrays on a metal substrate, titania powder film on transparent conductive substrate (e.g., FTO), and coating of titania on semiconducting arrays (Fig. 24 ). 3.3.1 One-dimensional structure to direct electron transport Self-organized anodic TiO2 nanotube arrays (NTAs), formed by anodizing a piece of Ti metal and adhered firmly on the Ti metal back contact, can be directly used as a working electrode [239,242,244,246–248,265]. These TiO2 NTAs are frequently working as the photoanode in the PEC system, and an additional p-type semiconductor is applied as the photocathode. A “photodiode” is created under bandgap illumination of such a p-n junction (Fig. 22(c)). In this configuration, TiO2 NTAs photoanode is applied to oxidize water through photogenerated holes, that produces gaseous oxygen and provides protons in turn for hydrocarbon fuel formation. A summary of the reported work using TiO2 NTAs as photoanode for CO2 reduction is shown in Table 4 . For example, using a photoanode of TiO2 NTAs, CO2 is converted to methane, ethylene, C3–C4 products, combined with a Cu-deposited p-Si as a photocathode [242]. In other work, different photocathode is employed, such as Pt coated graphene aerogel on cupper foam [246], Cu2O on Cu [259], Co/Ni/Sn phthalocyanine on Ni mesh [252], or Pt decorated reduced graphene oxide on nickel foam [247]. The one dimensional structure of TiO2 allows a fast separation of electron and holes due to the orthogonal separation. 3.3.2 Dope/fill with TiO2 1D arrays to enhance the activity To further enhance the activity of photoanode, the TiO2 NTAs electrode is modified with a secondary semiconductor that exhibits a narrowed bandgap, for example, InP [239], FeS2 [244], or a metal-organic complex [248,266]. With InP, the light adsorption is extended to the visible range, and the CBM shifts to –0.28 V, that improves the reduction ability of generated electrons. The photo-enhanced methanol production is 5.89 mmol·L−1, that is higher than that produced by sole electrolysis (3.85 mmol·L−1). By modification of FeS2 on TiO2 NTAs, not only the light absorption range shifts to visible range, the electrocatalytic resistance is reduced, which results in a methanol production rate of 91.7 μmol·h−1·L−1. TiO2 NTAs, with a high density of porosity, can be filled with functional materials, for example, ZIF-8, that acts as CO2 adsorption/activation sites as well as a co-catalyst [248]. In addition, Ru (II) pyridyl organic complex enhances the light absorption of TiO2 NTAs in the visible region and accelerates the separation of photoinduced electron-hole pairs [266]. The methanol production amount is 84.8 μmol at −0.9 V under 8 h irradiation, which is twice amount than that of TiO2 NTAs without Ru-pyridyl complex. Generally, the modifications on TiO2 in PEC are slightly different from those in photocatalysis, as external bias compensates the energy needed to activate CO2 thermodynamically. Thus, according to the overall efficiency equation (Eq. (1)), the approaches to improve the light absorption efficiency, the conductivity of the electrode and surface redox kinetics are more important than tuning the energetic band positions. However, in Fig. 22(c), the energetic positions of the two electrodes are still essential in the absence of external bias. 3.3.3 Applications of powdered TiO2 in the PEC TiO2 powders, except for the conventional use as suspensions, it can be prepared into a working electrode by spin coating, layer deposition, or doctor-blade. In these electrodes, TiO2 powder is modified with functional co-catalysts to improve the charge transfer kinetics [267–269]. For example, when metalloporphyrin functionalized TiO2 serves as a photocathode, methanol production rate reaches 55.5 μmol·L−1·h−1, with BiVO4 film as a photoanode [268]. In an advanced configuration, the counter electrode, BiVO4 film, is coated with Co-Pi and W, P25 electrode is modified with Pd nanoparticles (NPs), dye Eosin Y disodium salt and amine ligand. Within the electrode, dye molecules absorb solar energy, Pd NPs catch protons and the amine ligands capture and activate CO2 [269]. Hydrocarbon products are produced at a rate of 30–40 μmol·L−1·cm–2·h–1 and the selectivity is 100% at a bias of –0.5 V (vs. SCE). The modification strategies are similar to that of the one-dimensional TiO2 NTAs. 3.3.4 Improve the stability of PEC electrodes by coating TiO2 TiO2, as an excellent anticorrosion oxide, is applied as a coating film on semiconducting arrays to improve the stability of photo corrosive electrode and to regulate the charge state at the interface. Pati et al. [270] report a flat TiO2 (f-TiO2) and mesoporous TiO2 (m-TiO2) grafted Co-qPyH molecular catalyst. The protecting top TiO2 layer, combined with a Co-qPyH molecular catalyst, shows a high activity for CO2 conversion. Once the Co-qPyH|m-TiO2 electrode, connected to CIGS solar cells (ZnO:Al/ZnO/CdS/CIGS/Mo) in the PV-EC system, the selectivity toward CO reaches 87% at a bias of −0.06 V (vs. RHE). Furthermore, when the entire electrode is coated by a dense layer of f-TiO2, the selectivity toward CO reaches 97% due to the surface functionality of TiO2. Gong et al. [271] show that TiO2 film protects the amorphous Si thin film, that works as the light absorber in the photocathode. The catalytic layer on top of the electrode is grain boundary-rich Au NPs that catalyzes CO2 reduction. Due to the large photovoltage provided by the junction between amorphous silicon, TiO2, and grain boundary-rich Au NPs, the high-yield of syngas is achieved (Fig. 25 ). Except working as a protecting layer, Liu et al. [272] report the preparation of Au-TiO2 over InP nanopillar arrays, where the charge transfer between Au and TiO2 is locally confined to the interface, binding of the CO* intermediate is strengthened on the positively charged Au interfacial sites, thus CO2 to CO conversion efficiency is improved. The selectivity of CO2 reduction products in this configuration is thus tuned by the electric field between the three phases of the electrode. 3.4 DFT calculations Similar to the applications of DFT in the photocatalysis, the calculations using DFT theory are able to reveal the reaction pathways for CO2 reduction in PEC. Combined with in situ time-resolved spectroscopy, the investigations for CO2 reduction can be furthered advanced in the design of highly active and selective photoelectrocatalysts [19]. A typical example is shown by Wang et al. [230] that design a PEC system for CO2 conversion to CH3COOH with a Faradaic efficiency of 58.1% and carbon selectivity of 91.5% at 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. In this PEC cell, the Au/N-doped TiO2 is used as the photoanode and Zn0.015-doped Cu2O is employed as the cathode. The in situ Raman spectroscopy shows that the formation of *CO-*CH2 is the key step for C–C coupling, where the formation and adsorption of two intermediates (*CO, *CH2) mediate the pathway (Figs. 26(a) and 26(b) ). DFT calculation supports such reaction pathway by calculate the adsorption of intermediates, the key to the formation of CH3COOH on the surface of Zn-doped TiO2. The most favorable *CO adsorption configurations occur on the top site of Cu atoms that are adjacent to the two Zn sites on the surface the Zn0.015-doped Cu2O (Fig. 27(a) ), and on the top site of Cu atoms for the Cu2O (Fig. 27(c)). The most favorable *CH2 adsorption sites are on the bridge site of Zn–Zn on the surface of Zn0.015-doped Cu2O (Fig. 27(b)), and on the bridge site of Cu-Cu for Cu2O (Fig. 27(d)). The energy difference between the two adsorption configurations is 1.15 eV. Thus, both the adsorption of *CO and *CH2 intermediates are stronger on Zn-doped Cu2O than on Cu2O, favoring the C–C coupling via the *CO insertion mechanism. Through such a reaction pathway, the CO production is greatly suppressed. According to the theoretical calculations and the in situ Raman spectroscopy, the mechanism for CO2 conversion via C–C coupling over Zn-doped Cu2O can be proposed (Fig. 28 ). First, CO2 adsorbs on the Zn-doped Cu2O via two intermediate species, including *OCHO and *COOH. The *OCHO intermediate undergoes multi-step protons reduction to *CH2, which can then be adsorbed on the adjacent Zn sites. Simultaneously the *COOH intermediate converts to *CO and adsorbs on the top sites of Cu that are adjacent to the two Zn atoms. At last, the *CH2 and *CO intermediates are coupled and form a *CO-*CH2 intermediate, that is reduced and forming CH3COOH. 3.5 Further considerations In the photoelectrochemical setup, TiO2 is often applied as a photoanode to provide protons for the reduction of CO2. In alternative cases, using an oxidizing counter electrode, TiO2 works as a cathode to capture and activate CO2 on the active sites. Due to the intrinsically sluggish charge transfer kinetics of TiO2 under illumination or under electrochemical conditions, the properties of TiO2 should be modified with co-catalyst, or light adsorber before applications. Moreover, as an anti-photo-corrosive and anti-chemical corrosive oxide, TiO2 is used as a coating layer to protect the underneath functional electrode against photo corrosion and chemical corrosion. In PEC configuration, the main conversion products are C1 products, including CH4, methanol, and formic acid with a high selectivity, occasionally the products are C2 products such as ethanol, or acetic acid with ~50% selectivity. Carter et al. [273] have discussed the mechanism to produce methanol is based on the hydride transfer to CO2. Compared to photocatalysis in suspension, the selectivity and yield of C2 products are higher. Nevertheless, in aqueous solution, the liquid products need to be further separated and purified, that is beyond the scope this review. 4 Photothermal approach Photothermal catalysis is a promising way for the reduction of CO2 under mild conditions as the reaction utilize an extensive range of solar spectrum, that triggers both thermochemical and photochemical processes [274,275]. With the assist of focused solar irradiation, additional external thermal input can thus be decreased. An illustration of the reaction scheme is shown in Fig. 29 . Increasing attentions have been directed to the photothermal catalysis, in order to efficiently and selectively convert CO2 to CO, CH4 or other hydrocarbon products. Advantage of the process is the abundance and cheap CO2 and H2 or H2O vapor feedstocks reduces the cost of the reaction. During the photothermal catalytic reaction, the photocatalysis and thermal catalysis carry out simultaneously [276,277], which outperforms a single catalytic reaction performance. For instance, the energy of incident light does not need to be higher than the energy of the band gap, i.e., thermodynamically, the incident light energy does not determine the reaction anymore, which indicates a wide range of solar spectrum can be effectively utilized [38]. 4.1 Fundamentals for photothermal catalysis in CO2 reduction Differ from the PCs and PECs, photothermal reaction occurs in gas phase, with water vapor or hydrogen from solar water splitting. The reaction formula is displayed in Eq. (2) (reversed water gas shift reaction) and Eq. (3) [278]. (2) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O (3) CO2 + 2H2O → CH4 + 2O2 Under solar irradiation, the catalyst bed adsorbs solar radiation near-instantaneously and the electron transition is excited. The electrons at the conduction band and the holes at the valence band are separated in a time scale of femtoseconds that is an ultrafast process. The localized surface plasmonic resonance (LSPR) is a typical ultrafast process as well. In the photothermal catalysis, the heat transfer, mass transfer and molecular diffuse processes are controversially slow processes that take hundreds of picoseconds or even longer time to occur [38]. Therefore in the photothermal reaction, the kinetics of the slow process dominate the CO2 reduction reaction rate that is the redox reaction rate on the catalyst surface. In addition, for CO2 photothermal reduction process, the effective photons are concentrated in the high-frequency region, rather than the low-frequency photons. Thus, thermodynamically the external temperature input is the restricting step in the photothermal reaction of CO2 (Fig. 30 ) [279]. Consequently, the key to improve the conversion of CO2 is to improve the surface temperature of the catalyst and enhance the surface redox reaction kinetics. 4.2 Approaches to improve the efficiency for CO2 conversion As discussed in Section 4.1, the energy positions of CBM of the photocatalyst is not relevant in the photothermal CO2 reduction. Therefore, the principle to design catalyst for photothermal CO2 conversion is thus different from PCs or PECs. The most investigated materials for the photothermal CO2 reduction reactions are indium oxide, transition metals and few noble metals [38,280–285]. Titanium dioxide is reported to be active for photothermal CO2 conversion in anatase and rutile polymorphs [286]. To further improve the photothermal catalytic performance of TiO2, several aspects are summarized in Table 5 and illustrated in Fig. 31 . 4.2.1 Creation of surface frustrated lewis pairs (SFLPs) In 2007, Stephan et al. [299,300] have suggested that frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) own unique and unprecedented reactivity, which introduces numerous reactive sites in homogeneous inter- and intramolecular addition reaction. In heterogeneous catalysis, SFLPs have shown to be essential to impact the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the surface of a photocatalyst, thereby influence the activity and selectivity of the catalyst for CO2 reduction [94,274,286,301]. The bonding orbital and antibonding orbital of the CO2 molecule interact respectively with the empty orbitals in the Lewis acid sites and electron occupied orbitals of the Lewis base sites [94,302]. The adsorption and activation of CO2 can thus be tuned by the density and the acidity (capability to accept electrons) of the Lewis acid sites [303]. For instance, the creation of frustrated oxygen vacancy and proximal surface hydroxyls (Lewis pairs) on the surface of photocatalyst, such as CoGeO2(OH)2 [304] and In2O3–x (OH) y [305], can impact the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules [306]. Recently, SFLPs on anatase TiO2–x exhibit an outstanding ability for adsorption and activation of CO2 [307]. Without co-catalysts and sacrificial agents, the CO2 is converted to CO at a production rate 65.1 μmol·g–1·h−1 [307]. Alternatively, Chong et al. [308] immobilize MgAl layered double oxides (MgAl-LDO) on the surface of Pt/TiO2, that bring abundant strong Lewis pairs to TiO2. Consequently, a larger number of CO2 molecules are activated, as monodentate –CO3 2– and –HCO3 2–, and subsequently converted to –CO2 – on the surface. The reaction from –CO2 – species to CO and CH4 is more facile due to the nonlinear structure and lower bond energy of –CO2 –, compared to gaseous CO2 (Fig. 32 ). 4.2.2 Modifications by photothermal co-catalyst Decorating TiO2 with co-catalysts having photothermal properties can improve the overall catalytic performance of TiO2 by changing the local temperature during the catalysis. Black materials with wide absorption range can efficiently utilize the entire solar spectrum (from infrared to visible light to ultraviolet wavelength) and effectively reduce CO2 under mild conditions [38,309]. Ozin et al. [287,310] has developed a ternary heterogeneous structure catalyst, aiming to improve the backward reaction of water gas shift reaction (WGS) in photocatalysis. The layered nanotube arrays, containing TiN and TiO2, are used as scaffold for uniformly deposition of indium oxide, forming a TiN@TiO2@In2O3–x (OH) y photocatalyst. The improved performance of the catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation is ascribed to the photothermal effect of the black TiN (Fig. 33 ). The surface temperature of the photocatalyst increases from 58.9 to 116.4 °C under illumination and the yield of CH4 becomes 5.1 times higher, compared to single TiO2 phase. Wang et al. [296] synthesize a CuS/TiO2 composite for CO2 conversion under full-spectrum irradiation. CuS, a narrow band gap semiconductor (2.2 eV) [311], absorbs a large amount of solar light especially the infrared light, thus converts the solar energy into heat, e.g., the system temperature reaches at 138 °C. The utilization of solar energy is significantly improved, that promotes the catalytic CO2 conversion to CO. The yield of CO over 2% CuS/TiO2 composite under full spectrum irradiation is 25.97 μmol·g−1·h−1, that is three times higher than the yield of CO produced by single CuS or single TiO2. The decoration of graphene on TiO2 by hydrothermal treatment has also demonstrated an increased surface temperature to enhance the catalytic performance in the conversion of CO2 to CH4 [288]. 4.2.3 Conventional metal cocatalyst modification Deposition of noble metals on TiO2 can significantly improve the catalytic activity, ascribing to surface plasmonic effect of noble metal nanoparticles and increased adsorption sites for CO2 and intermediates [312]. Ye et al. [313] demonstrate that Group VIII metal nanoparticles (Ru, Rh, Ni, Co, Pd, Pt, Ir, and Fe) are able to convert CO2 into CH4 or CO with H2 under photothermal conditions. Co-catalyst loading with Pt or Ru on TiO2, leads to a conversion of CO2 with H2O into CH4 at 100% selectivity. However, the reaction rate is at low edge, in a magnitude of nmol·h–1·g–1 [313]. Xu et al. [289] prepare a palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs) loaded TiO2 photocatalyst, that shows a photothermal effect in the reduction of CO2 to CO. To further improve the conversion efficiency, Au NPs are coupled with oxygen vacancies on support TiO2 [290]. The catalytic performance of hydrogenated defective TiO2 shows a yield of CO at 6.71 μmol·g−1 and a yield of CH4 at 10.07 μmol·g−1, respectively. The CH4 production is impacted strongly by the competition between desorption and reduction of the key intermediates (CO*, HCOOH*, HCHO*, and CH3OH*) [314]. Li et al. [314] report that modification of Au and doping MgO on anatase TiO2 can enhance the electron transfer at the interface and inside the key intermediates, that significantly increases the CH4 selectivity (Fig. 34 ). He et al. [295] have developed CoO/Co/TiO2 to convert CO2 to methanol under light and heat conditions. The excited electrons from TiO2 could enhance the catalytic activity of metallic Co0 under thermal conditions. 13C trace labelling experiment shows that the methanol is produced from CO2. Recently, a ternary Bi/AgBiS2/P25 photocatalyst has been synthesized by one-step solvothermal reduction strategy for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [76]. The co-decoration of Bi/AgBiS2 can enhance the visible light harvest and electron delivery capability of P25. Moreover, due to the increased surface area, the number of active sites for CO2 reduction are enhanced, leading to an increase of CO adsorption efficiency. CO production increases from 3.52 to 6.37 μmol·g–1·h–1, CH4 production increases from 0.23 to 4.31 μmol·g–1·h–1 and CH4 selectivity improves from 2.54% to 73.17%. At the same time, the reaction temperature is stable at 50 °C. The photothermal effect works as a synergistic effect in the reaction. 4.3 DFT calculations in photothermal catalysis In photothermal reactions, DFT has been increasingly applied to reveal the reaction mechanism and guide the design of novel photocatalysts [315]. For example, the activation of Pd in CO2 reduction has been revealed by first-principles calculations in the density of states (DOS) and charge density using Pd-loaded anatase (101) models (Fig. 35 ) [289]. For the pure surface of Ti36O72 model (Fig. 35(a)), the DOS is symmetrical, indicating no magnetic moment (Fig. 35(b)). The Pd works as an electron capture center that leads to a shift of Femi level in DOS (Figs. 35(c) and 35(d)). As a result, the light absorption range and available carriers are increased, that may attribute to the enhanced catalytic performance. Furthermore, the reaction path can be revealed by the DFT calculation as well. For example, the formation energy can be used to evaluate the ease of a reaction. The formation energy of CO2 on Pd4-TiO2 is smaller than that on TiO2, indicating that Pd-CO2 –-VO could be formed more easily [289]. 4.4 Further considerations Titania, as a widely available metal oxide semiconductor, shows high promise to convert CO2 to CH4 and CO. Particularly, the solar fuel CH4, produced by the photothermal approaches, could eventually replace fossil CH4. However, up to now, in the solar power-to-gas (PtG) technology, the best-case solar-to-methane (CO2 methanation) efficiency is 13.0% [274], in which the hydrogen is produced by solar thermal water splitting or photocatalysis. In addition, to design a monolith photoreactor for gas-phase reduction of CO2 is essential: high illuminated surface area, high photon energy consumption, and high utilization of reactor volume [316,317]. The kinetic studies and process parameters on CO2 photoreduction should be considered, which are independent on the geometry of the reactor [318]. The limitation of current Langmuir-Hinshelwood-based kinetic models are introduced and used in the possible modelling of the system. It has been reported that the reduction rate of CO2 using MgO- and Pt-promoted TiO2 in the presence of H2O vapor is significantly higher than in the liquid H2O [165]. In conclusion, to implement the production of solar CH4, additional research work is needed to further improve the PtG efficiency, to scale up the production of solar CH4 to industrial scale, to rational design the reactors and catalysts, among others. 5 Experimental conditions in different configurations A typical reaction system in the photocatalysis is a gas-liquid-solid reaction, that contains CO2, water, and solid catalyst powder. The reaction usually takes place usually in an excessive CO2 condition. The catalyst powder is suspended in the solution as a slurry and CO2 is saturated in the liquid phase. In the case water vapor is introduced, the solid powder is placed on an inert support and face the quartz window of the rector. The reaction conditions in aqueous solution, e.g., the pH of the solution during photocatalysis affect selectivity of the products. Ishitani et al. [319] have demonstrated that under neutral conditions, HCOOH is selectively produced using Ru (II) and Ag double sites on TaON photocatalysts. However, in acidic electrolyte, the production of HCOOH competes with hydrogen production, thus the yield of HCOOH is low. Moreover, configuration of the photoreactor impacts on the products as well. In a stationary liquid phase or in the batch reactor, the products adsorb on the surface. For example, the accumulation of methoxy species on the surface of TiO2 is responsible for the deactivation of metal/TiO2 photocatalysts, therefore a flow reactor with H2O/CO2 is preferred over a fixed catalyst bed [157]. As for the photoelectrochemical reactions, the illustration of the reaction cell is shown in Fig. 21, with anodic cell, cathodic cell, a proton-exchange membrane and three electrodes. The electrolyte is usually acidic, for example, Na2SO4 aqueous solution saturated with CO2. For different targeted products, the electrolyte can be further optimized. A comparation between photocatalysis (PC), electrocatalysis (EC) and photoelectrochemical (PEC) techniques is analyzed to understand the effect of potential in the performance of the CO2 reduction. Fig. 36 show that the methanol formation under PEC technique is more than six folds higher than that obtained under PC and EC technique. However, the ethanol formation under PC was twice higher than the ethanol obtained under PEC technique. The difference in the products distribution can be attributed to the differences in the current densities and overvoltage that are applied to the working electrode [320]. In photothermal reactions, CO2 is added in the system as feed gas by a carrier gas, proton comes from vapor H2O splitting. The reaction is carried out in a stainless-steel reactor with quartz window with or without external heat, depending on the activity of the catalyst. The reaction temperature can be measured using an IR camera and usually is higher than 100 °C to maintain the water as vapor phase. The pressure of the reactor is usually higher than 1 atm, depending on the flow rate of inlet gas. 6 Summary and outlook In this review, the most recent progress on the reduction of CO2 using TiO2-based photocatalysts has been systematically summarized, including photocatalysis, photoelectrochemical catalysis in liquid phase and photothermal catalysis in gas phase. The thermodynamic and kinetic fundamentals are discussed in each configuration and thus the approaches to improve the efficiency of TiO2 based on the fundamentals have been summarized and discussed as well. Following aspects can be considered further to optimize the system. First, artificial intelligence in science based on the existing investigations can be applied to rationally design the novel photocatalyst. The development of supercomputing centers allows precise calculations and process big data. The evolution of operando instrument enables to reveal the underneath mechanism and probe the changes of catalysts during the reaction. The exploitation of titania in a photocatalytic system to convert CO2 into fine chemicals is challenging, but worth-developing and it is accompanied with the progress in material science and technologies. Second, in a photoelectrochemical system, the selectivity of products and conversion efficiency is higher than PCs. Though the photovoltaics have not been discussed in this review, a PEC system may be promising that can be operated in both day and night, where in the night the system can be driven by a battery system storing energy collected from a photovoltaic device. Third, in a photothermal catalytic system, the durability of catalyst at relative high temperature should be considered in the design of TiO2 that involves the thermal stability of TiO2, the mobility and aggregation of co-catalysts etc. The anchoring of the co-catalyst by chemical and physical bond may be a direction to avoid the mobile of co-catalyst. Except the scientific problems, the product separation and purification are the main technology that need to be developed to scale up the reaction. Extra efforts are made towards the design of the reactor that maximize the harvest and conversion of solar energy. Like the solar-driven water splitting devices, only the cost and efficiency meet the demands, the devices can be efficiently scaled up [321,322]. In summary, in this review we summarize the photoelectrochemical, photocatalytic and photothermal approaches to produce solar fuels. Specifically, the fundamentals and methods that activate titania are discussed and summarized. We try to provide a comprehensive overview on the CO2 conversion using titania-based photocatalysts that may be applied to other semiconducting metal oxides. coredata.dc:description: Solar-driven CO2 reduction is an efficient way to convert sustainable solar energy and massive CO2 to renewable solar fuels, such as CH4, HCOOH, HCHO, and CH3OH, etc. Up to now, significant research efforts have been devoted to exploring the reaction path and developing the photocatalysts. In heterogeneous photocatalysis, among the semiconductor-based photocatalysts, titania (TiO2), as an inexpensive and practically sustainable metal oxides, remains the most extensively studied photocatalyst over the past decades. In this review, we summarize the most recent advances in the solar-driven CO2 reduction using TiO2-based photocatalysts, which include the fabrication of heterojunction, surface functional modification, band structure engineering, and morphology design, aiming to improve the CO2 conversion efficiency and selectivity to the desired product. Additionally, photoelectrochemical and photothermal approaches are introduced and the fundamental principles to activate and enhance the performance of TiO2 for the specific reaction are discussed. The exploration of the solar-driven approaches and discussion on the underlying mechanism allow the comprehensive understanding of CO2 photoreduction, that can lead to a rational design and synthesis of TiO2-based photocatalysts.
